title: Recognizing and Avoiding Whiteout Travel
brief: How to identify whiteout conditions and why travel should be avoided.
steps: Step 1: Recognize whiteout conditions by the lack of contrasting colors in your field of vision.
Step 2: Test terrain visibility by looking for shadows, depth perception, and ground features.
Step 3: If you cannot judge the nature of the terrain ahead, stop travel immediately.
Step 4: Wait in shelter until visibility improves before continuing travel.
warnings: Whiteout conditions make it impossible to see obstacles, cliffs, or dangerous terrain.
Continuing travel in whiteout can lead to falls, getting lost, or walking into hazards.
Depth perception is completely compromised in whiteout conditions.
